content.webTitle: Brundibár review – WNO bring passion and poignancy to Terezin opera

fields.headline: Brundibár review – WNO bring passion and poignancy to Terezin opera
fields.bodyText: Hans Krása’s children’s opera is, on the surface of it, a simple allegory about children whose intrinsic goodness and willingness to help each other gets the better of the bullying organ-grinder Brundibár, Czech for bumblebee. But those who sang the piece first in the Jewish orphanage in Prague and then in the ghetto camp of Theresienstadt (Terezín), knew perfectly well that the bully represented Hitler. The message that he could be defeated was symbolic: performing together brought hope and made them feel human, yet most of those children went to their deaths in Auschwitz not long after, as did Krása himself. Forming an emotional postlude to Welsh National Opera’s Freedom season and the theme of human rights, the innocent brightness of the WNO children’s chorus, the shining commitment and talent of the two youngsters, Manon Thomas and Alfie Jones, as Aninku and Pepiček, who sing to get money to buy milk for their ailing mother, came over vividly. It was all the more moving for clearly being a promise fulfilled by WNO’s music director, Tomáš Hanus. His mother, Anna Hanusova-Flachova, was one of those who sang it in Terezín. She survived thanks to an administrative error. Krása’s music is uncomplicatedly tuneful, direct and appealing: Hanus conducted with passion, his own children joining in a reprise of the final rousing chorus. There was a colourful immediacy to David Pountney’s staging, but this was no cocooned-in-cotton-wool affair. The audience had filed in past metal railings wound with barbed wire, each member given a yellow scarf by a Nazi guard. Sharp toots of his whistle brought the children marching in. Steffan Lloyd Owen as Brundibár was a suitably pantomimic villain, and the rest of the young cast were equally adept. The brief opera was reinforced by a short documentary using footage of the propaganda film shot at Terezín, with Hanus’s own account linking us to the present. Last came testimony in person from 90-year-old Ellen Davis who, separated from her family, left Germany on Kindertransport. Her heartfelt appeal was quietly delivered: “This is happening again, do something to stop it.”
